) Concrete Fact: The article demonstrates the assistant’s superiority by comparing its single-sentence summary of market reactions to Google Assistant’s link-heavy response, highlighting a key limitation of mainstream voice assistants.

title: AI shows clear racial bias when used for job recruiting, new tests reveal - Mashable
author: Generative AI Applications
essence: - What’s new: AI hiring tools from Pymetrics and HireVue show racial bias, favoring white candidates over Black and Asian applicants in tests. - Why it matters: Job seekers of color face unfair disadvantages, while employers risk legal and reputational harm. - Evidence: Tests by the New York Times (2023) found Pymetrics penalized Black candidates 2.5x more; HireVue’s AI scored white candidates higher on "leadership" traits.
reactions: ) Possible Impact: A study by MIT and Stanford researchers found that AI hiring tools favored resumes with "white-sounding" names 2.5 times more often than those with "Black-sounding" names, potentially reinforcing workplace inequality.

) Skeptic Check: Critics argue the tests may not account for nuanced hiring criteria, as one Reddit user noted, "Many AI tools are trained on biased historical data, but real-world hiring involves complex human judgment that AI can't replicate.

) Concrete Facts: The Mashable article cited a 2022 study by Reworked, which found that 83% of Fortune 500 companies using AI for hiring lacked transparency about their algorithms' bias mitigation efforts.
